title: Manipuri
short_description: Known for its gentle, modest, and lyrical movements, often depicting the Raslila of Radha and Krishna.
long_description:
Manipuri dance, also known as Jagoi, originates from the northeastern state of Manipur. It is distinct from other Indian classical forms due to its emphasis on sinuous, curvilinear movements and the absence of sharp, stiff gestures. The feet never strike the ground hard; movements are light and floating, resembling the swaying of trees.

The most famous repertoire is the Raslila, depicting the cosmic dance of Krishna and the Gopis. The costumes are unique, particularly the stiff, cylindrical mirror-work skirt (Kumil) worn by female dancers. Another vigorous aspect is the Pung Cholom, where male dancers play the Pung (drum) while performing acrobatic jumps and spins.
costume_and_makeup: The Kumil (stiff barrel-shaped skirt) decorated with mirrors and embroidery is iconic. A transparent veil covers the face, adding an ethereal quality. Male dancers wear dhotis and turbans.
where_to_learn: Jawaharlal Nehru Manipur Dance Academy, Imphal

practical_info.audience_tips: The pace is slow and meditative compared to other forms. Patience yields spiritual rewards.
